title: We Work founder Adam Neumann scoops £1.3bn in rescue deal
text:
A rescue bid for the troubled temporary office space provider We Work will see its co-founder walk away with a £1.3billion package.

The deal proposed by Softbank will reportedly see the Japanese investor buy roughly £775million of shares from Adam Neumann, giving it majority control of the business.

Softbank will also pay the 40-year-old a £143million consulting fee and extend to him £387million in credit to help repay loans, according to the Wall Street Journal.

Fall from grace: But We Work founder Adam Neumann is set to walk away with a £1.3bn package

The rescue will prevent We Work from running short of cash, after it was forced to pull plans for a stock market float last month.

But it is still expected to be followed by thousands of job losses and Neumann will have a significantly diminished role.

He will step down as chairman – just weeks after he was forced to resign as chief executive – and quit the board, staying on only as an observer.

It marks a dramatic fall from grace for the entrepreneur who co-founded We Work with his wife Rebekah, 41, and friend Miguel McKelvey, 45, in 2010.

He had been credited for leading his firm to a lofty valuation of £36.3billion in nine years. But that has crashed down to £6.2billion, and it is battling to survive.

This extraordinary drop, just like We Work's rise, has been inextricably linked to Neumann.

As the company's hard-partying and unorthodox chief executive, he helped it grow from a tiny New York start-up to a global behemoth with 15,000 staff and offices in 123 cities.

Neumann, pictured with wife Rebekah, had the reputation of a hard-partying and unorthodox chief executive

It soon became known for its aggressive expansion, trendy locations and, famously, free beer on its premises for customers.

It aimed to 'elevate the world's consciousness' – echoing the culture of many of Silicon Valley's flashiest firms.

Such was Neumann's influence that when the company published its stock market prospectus, the risk of him leaving was listed as a 'material adverse effect on our business'.

But as more and more gaffes emerged during the flotation process, investors began to worry about the former chief executive for very different reasons.

Concerns emerged about its widening £1.5billion losses, Neumann's control over some properties that We Work rented and his tight grip on the company via an unusual share structure.

Reports he had sold the 'We' trademark to his firm for £4.6million and allegedly used drugs on company premises also unnerved potential backers.

We Work had to call off the float, with Neumann ousted as chief executive by Softbank which at that stage owned one- third of shares.

He will now exit the company almost entirely and Softbank's Marcelo Claure will be tasked, as the new chairman, with halting We Work's rapid decline.

Analysts have said that We Work's tumbling fortunes are partly a result of the mystique that surrounded it – despite the fact that it is essentially a property company.

John Colley, of Warwick Business School, previously noted it had 'slick marketing' but was losing money hand over fist. He said: 'Fundamentally, We Work finances do not look good.'

We Work did not respond to requests for comment last night, and Softbank also declined to comment.
